preface.p: Pakistan civil and corporate law compilation for EZ Stack sovereign deployment. This document consolidates key provisions from the Companies Act 2017 (Act No. XL of 2017), the Contract Act 1872 (Act No. IX of 1872), the Special Economic Zones Act 2012 (Act No. XII of 2012), and the Partnership Act 1932 (Act No. IX of 1932) as in force on 1 January 2024.
This compilation is provided for machine-readable regulatory analysis. It does not replace the official gazette text. All section numbers correspond to the published Acts.

content.p: (1) Any one or more persons associated for a lawful purpose may, by subscribing their names to a memorandum of association and complying with the requirements of this Act in respect of registration, form a private company.
(2) Any three or more persons so associated may form a public company.
(3) One person may form a single member company.

(4) An application for incorporation shall be filed with the registrar in the prescribed form and shall be accompanied by the following documents: (a) the memorandum of association; (b) the articles of association; (c) a declaration of compliance in the prescribed form; (d) the notice of the situation of the registered office; (e) a copy of the national identity card or passport of each subscriber; (f) particulars of the first directors and chief executive; and (g) such fee as may be prescribed.

(5) On registration, the registrar shall issue a certificate of incorporation in the prescribed form, and the company shall from the date of incorporation be a body corporate with perpetual succession and a common seal, capable of exercising all functions of an incorporated company under this Act.

(1) The memorandum of every company shall state: (a) the name of the company with "Limited" or "(Private) Limited" as the last word; (b) the province in which the registered office of the company is to be situated; (c) the objects for which the company is proposed to be formed; (d) the liability of the members; and (e) the amount of authorized share capital with which the company is to be registered and the division thereof into shares of a fixed amount.

(2) The memorandum of a company limited by guarantee shall also state that each member undertakes to contribute to the assets of the company in the event of its being wound up while he is a member or within one year after he ceases to be a member, such amount as may be required, not exceeding a specified amount.
(3) In the case of a private company, the minimum paid-up capital shall be one hundred thousand rupees (PKR 100,000) or such other amount as may be prescribed by the Commission.
(4) In the case of a public company, the minimum paid-up capital shall be two hundred thousand rupees (PKR 200,000) or such other amount as the Commission may prescribe.
(1) There shall be registered with the memorandum articles of association signed by each subscriber to the memorandum prescribing regulations for the company.
(2) Articles shall be in the form set out in Table A of the First Schedule or in a form as near thereto as circumstances admit, or in such other form as the Commission may approve.

(3) The articles shall be printed, divided into paragraphs numbered consecutively, and signed by each subscriber to the memorandum in the presence of at least one witness who shall attest the signature and shall likewise add his description and address.

(4) The articles may contain provisions for the management of the company's affairs including: (a) the transfer and transmission of shares; (b) the increase and reduction of share capital; (c) the convening and conduct of general meetings; (d) the appointment, powers, duties and remuneration of directors; (e) the payment of dividends; and (f) the keeping of accounts and audit.
(1) Every company having a share capital shall in each year hold an annual general meeting in addition to any other meetings and shall specify the meeting as such in the notices calling it.
(2) The first annual general meeting of a company shall be held within a period of eighteen months from the date of its incorporation.

(3) Subsequent annual general meetings shall be held at intervals of not more than fifteen months, provided that the company shall hold an annual general meeting in each calendar year and not more than four months shall elapse between the date of one annual general meeting of the company and the last day of the following financial year.

(4) At every annual general meeting of a company, the following business shall be transacted: (a) consideration of the accounts, balance sheet and the reports of the directors and auditors; (b) the election or appointment of directors in place of those retiring; (c) the appointment of and the fixing of the remuneration of auditors; and (d) such other matters as may be prescribed or required under this Act.

(5) If default is made in holding an annual general meeting, the Commission may, on the application of any member of the company, call or direct the calling of an annual general meeting and give such ancillary or consequential directions as the Commission thinks expedient.

(1) Every company shall keep at its registered office proper books of account with respect to: (a) all sums of money received and expended by the company and the matters in respect of which the receipt and expenditure takes place; (b) all sales and purchases of goods by the company; (c) the assets and liabilities of the company; and (d) in the case of a company engaged in production, processing, manufacturing or mining activities, such particulars relating to utilization of material, labour and other items of overhead cost as may be prescribed.

(2) The books of account shall give a true and fair view of the state of affairs of the company and explain its transactions and shall be kept on accrual basis and according to the double entry system of accounting.

(3) Where a company has a branch office, whether in or outside Pakistan, the company shall ensure that proper books of account relating to the transactions effected at the branch office are kept at that office and proper summarized returns are sent to the registered office at intervals of not more than three months.

(4) The books of account of every company shall be preserved in good order for a period of not less than ten years from the date of the last entry therein, and where an investigation has been ordered, until the conclusion of the investigation.

(5) If any director or officer of the company fails to take reasonable steps to secure compliance with the requirements of this section or has by his own wilful act been the cause of any default, he shall be liable to a penalty which may extend to five hundred thousand rupees (PKR 500,000).
(1) Every company shall prepare an annual return and file it with the registrar within thirty days from the date of each annual general meeting.

(2) The annual return shall be in the prescribed form and shall contain the following particulars as at the date of the annual general meeting: (a) the registered office; (b) a summary of share capital, debentures and charges; (c) the indebtedness of the company in respect of all charges which are required to be registered; (d) a list of members showing the shares held by each member and changes therein since the last return; (e) particulars of directors, chief executive, auditors and legal adviser and changes therein; and (f) such other particulars as may be prescribed.
(3) The annual return of a company having a share capital shall also include a certified copy of the audited financial statements as laid before the company in its annual general meeting.

(4) If a company fails to file its annual return within the period specified, the company and every officer who is in default shall be liable to a penalty of one hundred rupees (PKR 100) for each day of default, subject to a maximum of five hundred thousand rupees (PKR 500,000).

(1) A company may be wound up by the Tribunal if: (a) the company has by special resolution resolved that the company be wound up by the Tribunal; (b) the company has made a default in filing with the registrar its financial statements or annual returns for five consecutive financial years; (c) the company has acted against the interests of the sovereignty and integrity of Pakistan, the security of the state, friendly relations with foreign states, public order, decency or morality; (d) the Tribunal is of the opinion that it is just and equitable that the company should be wound up; (e) the company is unable to pay its debts; (f) the company has not commenced its business within a year from its incorporation and the Tribunal is of the opinion that the company was formed without bona fide intent to carry on business; or (g) the affairs of the company have been conducted in a manner oppressive to any member or in disregard of his interests as member.

(2) A company shall be deemed to be unable to pay its debts if: (a) a creditor by assignment or otherwise to whom the company is indebted in a sum exceeding the prescribed amount then due has served on the company a demand requiring the company to pay the sum so due and the company has for three weeks thereafter neglected to pay the sum; or (b) execution or other process issued on a decree or order of any court in favour of a creditor of the company is returned unsatisfied; or (c) it is proved to the satisfaction of the Tribunal that the company is unable to pay its debts, taking into account the contingent and prospective liabilities of the company.

section.heading: Company formation in Special Economic Zones

content.p: (1) Notwithstanding anything contained in this Act, the Commission may, in consultation with the federal government, prescribe simplified procedures for the incorporation of companies within Special Economic Zones established under the Special Economic Zones Act, 2012.

(2) Such simplified procedures may include: (a) one-window registration combining company incorporation, tax registration and social security enrolment; (b) electronic filing and processing of all incorporation documents; (c) reduced timelines for issuance of certificates of incorporation; and (d) simplified forms and requirements for small and medium enterprises.
(3) The Commission may establish a dedicated desk or portal for companies being formed within Economic Zones and may coordinate with the zone authority for the purpose of registration and regulation.
(4) Companies incorporated under this section shall be subject to all provisions of this Act except to the extent modified by rules made under this section.

section.heading: Reduced paid-up capital requirements for Economic Zone companies

content.p: (1) Notwithstanding section 17, the Commission may prescribe reduced minimum paid-up capital requirements for companies formed and operating exclusively within a Special Economic Zone notified under the Special Economic Zones Act, 2012.
(2) Such reduced requirements shall not be less than: (a) fifty thousand rupees (PKR 50,000) for a private company; and (b) one hundred thousand rupees (PKR 100,000) for a public company.

(3) A company availing the reduced paid-up capital under this section shall not commence business outside the Economic Zone without first increasing its paid-up capital to the minimum prescribed under section 17 and obtaining fresh approval from the registrar.

When one person signifies to another his willingness to do or to abstain from doing anything, with a view to obtaining the assent of that other to such act or abstinence, he is said to make a proposal.
When the person to whom the proposal is made signifies his assent thereto, the proposal is said to be accepted. A proposal, when accepted, becomes a promise.
The person making the proposal is called the promisor, and the person accepting the proposal is called the promisee.

When, at the desire of the promisor, the promisee or any other person has done or abstained from doing, or does or abstains from doing, or promises to do or to abstain from doing, something, such act or abstinence or promise is called a consideration for the promise.
Every promise and every set of promises, forming the consideration for each other, is an agreement.
An agreement enforceable by law is a contract.
An agreement which is enforceable by law at the option of one or more of the parties thereto, but not at the option of the other or others, is a voidable contract.
An agreement not enforceable by law is said to be void.

All agreements are contracts if they are made by the free consent of parties competent to contract, for a lawful consideration and with a lawful object, and are not hereby expressly declared to be void.

Nothing herein contained shall affect any law in force in Pakistan and not hereby expressly repealed by which any contract is required to be made in writing or in the presence of witnesses, or any law relating to the registration of documents.

Every person is competent to contract who is of the age of majority according to the law to which he is subject, and who is of sound mind, and is not disqualified from contracting by any law to which he is subject.
Consent is said to be so caused when it would not have been given but for the existence of such coercion, undue influence, fraud, misrepresentation or mistake.

Coercion is the committing, or threatening to commit, any act forbidden by the Pakistan Penal Code, or the unlawful detaining, or threatening to detain, any property, to the prejudice of any person whatever, with the intention of causing any person to enter into an agreement.

section.heading: What considerations and objects are lawful, and what not

content.p: The consideration or object of an agreement is lawful, unless it is forbidden by law; or is of such a nature that, if permitted, it would defeat the provisions of any law; or is fraudulent; or involves or implies injury to the person or property of another; or the Court regards it as immoral, or opposed to public policy.
In each of these cases, the consideration or object of an agreement is said to be unlawful. Every agreement of which the object or consideration is unlawful is void.

section.heading: Agreement without consideration void, unless in writing and registered

content.p: An agreement made without consideration is void, unless: (1) it is expressed in writing and registered under the law for the time being in force for the registration of documents, and is made on account of natural love and affection between parties standing in a near relation to each other; or (2) it is a promise to compensate, wholly or in part, a person who has already voluntarily done something for the promisor, or something which the promisor was legally compellable to do; or (3) it is a promise, made in writing and signed by the person to be charged therewith, or by his agent generally or specially authorized in that behalf, to pay wholly or in part a debt of which the creditor might have enforced payment but for the law for the limitation of suits.

section.heading: Compensation for loss or damage caused by breach of contract

content.p: When a contract has been broken, the party who suffers by such breach is entitled to receive, from the party who has broken the contract, compensation for any loss or damage caused to him thereby, which naturally arose in the usual course of things from such breach, or which the parties knew, when they made the contract, to be likely to result from the breach of it.
Such compensation is not to be given for any remote and indirect loss or damage sustained by reason of the breach.

When an obligation resembling those created by contract has been incurred and has not been discharged, any person injured by the failure to discharge it is entitled to receive the same compensation from the party in default, as if such person had contracted to discharge it and had broken his contract.

section.heading: Compensation for breach of contract where penalty stipulated for

content.p: When a contract has been broken, if a sum is named in the contract as the amount to be paid in case of such breach, or if the contract contains any other stipulation by way of penalty, the party complaining of the breach is entitled, whether or not actual damage or loss is proved to have been caused thereby, to receive from the party who has broken the contract reasonable compensation not exceeding the amount so named or, as the case may be, the penalty stipulated for.

section.heading: Party rightfully rescinding contract entitled to compensation

content.p: A person who rightfully rescinds a contract is entitled to compensation for any damage which he has sustained through the non-fulfilment of the contract.

part.heading: Special Economic Zones Act 2012 (Act No. XII of 2012)

content.p: In this Act, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context:

item.p: "Approval Board" means the Board of Approval constituted under section 4;
"developer" means a person who has been granted permission under this Act to develop a Special Economic Zone;
"domestic tariff area" means the whole of Pakistan except the Special Economic Zones;

content.p: (1) The federal government may, by notification in the official Gazette, establish one or more Special Economic Zones in any part of Pakistan.

(2) A provincial government or a private sector entity may propose the establishment of a Special Economic Zone in any area of the province, and the Approval Board shall consider and approve or reject such proposals on the basis of criteria prescribed by rules.

(1) There shall be constituted a Board of Approval for the purposes of this Act, consisting of: (a) the Prime Minister or his nominee, who shall be chairperson; (b) the Chief Ministers of the provinces or their nominees; (c) the federal ministers for finance, commerce, industries and production, and planning; (d) the chairman of the Board of Investment; (e) two representatives of the private sector nominated by the federal government; and (f) such other members as the federal government may determine.

(2) The Board of Approval shall approve proposals for the establishment of Special Economic Zones, prescribe the terms and conditions for the grant of permits to developers, and review the performance of Special Economic Zones.
(3) The Board of Approval shall meet at least twice a year at such place and time as the chairperson may determine.

(1) The Board of Investment shall establish a One Window Operation at the federal level for the purpose of providing facilitation to zone developers and zone enterprises in obtaining all regulatory approvals, licences and permits required under any law.
(2) Each provincial government shall establish a provincial One Window Operation for facilitating zone developers and zone enterprises within the province.
(3) The One Window Operation shall have representatives of all relevant federal and provincial departments, and shall process applications within thirty days of receipt of a complete application.

(1) The zone developer shall: (a) develop the infrastructure of the Special Economic Zone as specified in the development agreement, including roads, drainage, water supply, electricity, gas, telecommunications and waste disposal; (b) allocate space and provide developed plots or built-up space to zone enterprises; (c) ensure that the Special Economic Zone is demarcated and fenced or otherwise physically segregated from the domestic tariff area; (d) maintain common facilities and shared infrastructure; and (e) comply with all environmental laws and regulations applicable to the zone.
(2) The zone developer shall submit an annual report to the Board of Investment detailing the development progress, occupancy rates, investment levels, and employment generated within the zone.

(1) Any person, whether a company registered under the Companies Act or an association of persons, may apply to set up a zone enterprise, provided that: (a) the applicant proposes to carry on a business activity as approved for the zone; (b) the minimum investment is not less than the amount prescribed for the category of zone enterprise; and (c) the applicant has not been convicted of an offence involving fraud, tax evasion, or money laundering within the five years preceding the application.
(2) Preference shall be given to applications from enterprises proposing to undertake manufacturing, processing, assembling, or value-added services that generate employment and promote exports.
(3) A zone enterprise shall not undertake any activity prohibited by any law for the time being in force or any activity that the Board of Approval may specify as prohibited for a particular zone.
(1) Upon approval of an application under section 13, the zone authority shall issue a licence to the zone enterprise in the prescribed form.

(2) The licence shall specify: (a) the nature and scope of the business activities; (b) the area allocated within the zone; (c) the period of the licence and conditions for renewal; (d) the obligations of the enterprise regarding employment, investment and export targets; and (e) such other conditions as the zone authority may prescribe.

(1) Zone enterprises shall be exempt from import licensing requirements for goods imported into the zone for use in the manufacturing, processing, assembling or packaging of goods intended for export.

(2) Goods manufactured, processed, assembled or packaged within a zone may be exported without an export licence, provided that the zone enterprise maintains proper records of all imports and exports as prescribed by customs regulations.

(3) The movement of goods between a Special Economic Zone and the domestic tariff area shall be treated as import into or export from Pakistan and shall be subject to applicable customs duties and regulations, save as otherwise provided in this Act.

(1) Subject to the conditions laid down in this Act and rules made thereunder, a zone enterprise that commences commercial production within the zone on or after the date of notification of the zone shall be entitled to exemption from income tax for a period of ten years from the date of commencement of commercial production.
(2) The ten-year exemption from income tax under sub-section (1) shall apply to income derived exclusively from operations within the Special Economic Zone.
(3) Zone developers shall be entitled to exemption from income tax for a period of ten years from the date of signing of the development agreement.

(4) The federal government may, by notification in the official Gazette, prescribe further tax incentives or modify the period of exemption for specific zones or categories of zone enterprises, having regard to the national interest and the objectives of this Act.

(5) A zone enterprise that relocates from the domestic tariff area to a Special Economic Zone shall not be eligible for the exemption under this section unless it makes new investment of the prescribed minimum amount.

section.heading: Exemption from sales tax and federal excise duty

content.p: (1) All goods imported into a Special Economic Zone for the purpose of a zone enterprise shall be exempt from sales tax and federal excise duty, subject to the conditions prescribed by rules.
(2) This exemption applies only where the goods are consumed or utilized within the zone or are incorporated into goods exported from the zone.

section.heading: Customs duty exemption on capital goods

content.p: (1) Capital goods, including plant, machinery and equipment, imported into a Special Economic Zone by a zone developer or zone enterprise for the development, operation or maintenance of the zone or for use in manufacturing, processing, assembling or other authorized activities within the zone shall be exempt from customs duties.

(2) The exemption under sub-section (1) shall be subject to the following conditions: (a) the capital goods shall be used exclusively within the zone; (b) the zone developer or zone enterprise shall furnish an undertaking to customs authorities that the goods will not be sold or transferred to the domestic tariff area without payment of applicable duties; (c) the zone developer or zone enterprise shall maintain a register of all duty-free imports and make it available for inspection by customs officers; and (d) any transfer of duty-exempt capital goods to the domestic tariff area shall be subject to payment of customs duty calculated on the depreciated value of the goods at the rates applicable at the time of such transfer.
(3) Raw materials and intermediary goods imported for use in the manufacturing or processing of goods for export shall be exempt from customs duties subject to such conditions as may be prescribed.
(1) All labour laws in force in Pakistan shall apply to Special Economic Zones.

(2) Notwithstanding sub-section (1), the federal government may, by notification in the official Gazette and in consultation with the provinces, provide for simplified labour compliance procedures within zones, provided that the core labour standards recognized under international conventions ratified by Pakistan shall not be derogated.
"Partnership" is the relation between persons who have agreed to share the profits of a business carried on by all or any of them acting for all.

Persons who have entered into partnership with one another are called individually "partners" and collectively "a firm," and the name under which their business is carried on is called the "firm name."

section.heading: Relation of partnership arising from contract

content.p: The relation of partnership arises from contract and not from status; and, in particular, the members of a Hindu undivided family carrying on a family business as such, or a Burmese Buddhist husband and wife carrying on business as such, are not partners in such business.

section.heading: Every partner is agent of the firm

content.p: Subject to the provisions of this Act, every partner is the agent of the firm for the purposes of the business of the firm. The act of every partner which is done to carry on, in the usual way, business of the kind carried on by the firm, binds the firm, unless the partner so acting has in fact no authority to act for the firm in the particular matter, and the person with whom he is dealing knows that he has no such authority, or does not know or believe him to be a partner.

(1) The registration of a firm may be effected at any time by filing with the Registrar of Firms an application stating: (a) the firm name; (b) the place or principal place of business of the firm; (c) the names of any other places where the firm carries on business; (d) the date when each partner joined the firm; (e) the names in full and permanent addresses of the partners; and (f) the duration of the firm.
(2) The application shall be signed by all the partners, or by their agents specially authorized in this behalf.

(3) No suit to enforce a right arising from a contract shall be instituted in any court by or on behalf of any person suing as a partner in a firm against the firm or against any person alleged to be or to have been a partner in the firm unless the firm is registered and the person suing is or has been shown in the Register of Firms as a partner in the firm.

For EZ Stack zone deployments in Pakistan, the minimum incorporation requirements are: (a) private company: at least one subscriber, minimum paid-up capital PKR 100,000 (or PKR 50,000 within a notified SEZ per section 461 Companies Act 2017); (b) public company: at least three subscribers, minimum paid-up capital PKR 200,000 (or PKR 100,000 within a notified SEZ); (c) single member company: one subscriber, minimum paid-up capital PKR 100,000.

Documents required: memorandum of association, articles of association, declaration of compliance, registered office notice, NIC/passport copies of subscribers, and particulars of first directors and chief executive (section 16 Companies Act 2017).

Every registered company must: (a) hold an AGM within 18 months of incorporation and annually thereafter, with not more than 15 months between consecutive AGMs (section 85 Companies Act 2017); (b) file an annual return with the registrar within 30 days of the AGM (section 131); (c) maintain books of account on accrual basis for a minimum of 10 years (section 119).
Penalties for non-compliance: late annual return filing attracts PKR 100 per day of default, maximum PKR 500,000. Failure to maintain accounting records: director/officer penalty up to PKR 500,000.

Zone enterprises commencing commercial production within a notified SEZ are entitled to: (a) ten-year income tax exemption from date of commercial production commencement (section 37 SEZ Act 2012); (b) exemption from sales tax and federal excise on goods imported for zone use (section 38); (c) customs duty exemption on capital goods including plant, machinery and equipment (section 39); (d) import licensing waiver for goods used in export manufacturing (section 23); (e) simplified one-window registration (section 7, read with section 460 Companies Act 2017).
Zone developers are separately entitled to a ten-year income tax exemption from the date of signing the development agreement (section 37(3) SEZ Act 2012).
Restriction: enterprises relocating from the domestic tariff area to an SEZ must make new investment of the prescribed minimum to qualify for the ten-year exemption (section 37(5)).

section.heading: Contract validity requirements for EZ transactions

content.p: All agreements executed within or in connection with an EZ-governed zone must satisfy the requirements of the Contract Act 1872: (a) free consent of parties competent to contract (sections 10, 11, 14); (b) lawful consideration and lawful object (section 23); (c) agreement not declared void under the Act (section 10). Agreements that fail these conditions are void ab initio and unenforceable.

For digital contracts executed through EZ Stack platform: electronic signatures are recognized under the Electronic Transactions Ordinance 2002 (Ordinance No. LI of 2002), provided that the signatory has consented and the method of signature creation is reliable and linked to the signatory.

Grounds for compulsory winding up by the Tribunal include: (a) special resolution for winding up; (b) five consecutive years of failure to file financial statements or annual returns; (c) acts against sovereignty, public order or morality; (d) just and equitable ground; (e) inability to pay debts; (f) failure to commence business within one year; (g) oppressive or prejudicial conduct of affairs (section 237 Companies Act 2017).

A company is deemed unable to pay its debts if a creditor's statutory demand exceeding the prescribed amount remains unsatisfied for three weeks, or execution is returned unsatisfied, or the Tribunal is otherwise satisfied of insolvency including contingent and prospective liabilities.

Under section 69 of the Partnership Act 1932, an unregistered firm cannot institute a suit to enforce a contractual right. EZ Stack zone deployments should ensure that partnership entities operating within the zone are registered with the Registrar of Firms. Every partner acts as agent of the firm (section 25) and can bind the firm in the usual course of business.
